titleStmt.title: M110 [The Reader: Spenser with his eye upon the reader in the great room.]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 5p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M110 [The Reader: Spenser with his eye upon the reader in the great room.]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 5p.
Paginated 26-30. On verso of p. 29, a fragment from Between the Acts, paginated 186.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p:
with his eye upon the reader in the great room.
Yet the audience for all its size and compulsion is silent.

p.sup:
If we
could (cd.) measure
the effect
of the audience
we should (shd.)
have a hold
upon the
play.

div.p:
That is one of the deep gulfs that lies between us
and the play. They crowd there; daily; but they neither
praise (priase) nor blame. We must compare it with our own (won) silence (sielnce)
at the or the
A new art comes upon us so surprisingly (surpinsgly) that we sit
silent, recognising what we cannot measure.
To the Elizabethans the expressive power of words
after their long inadequacy must (ust) have been overwhelming.
There at the or at the men and women whose only
reading had been the Bible or some old chronicle (chonicle) came out
into the light of the present moment. They saw themselves
splendidly dressed. They heard themselves (themslves) saying out loud
what they had never said yet. They heard their aspirations,
their profanities, their ribaldries (ribaldires) spoken out loud by human
voices in poetry.

The play then owes its hyperbole to the audience in the
penny seats. At their command it is violent (vio;ent); it xmxmxmmxmx
it is coarse; it is poexxx xmxmxmxm a parody, of actual
facts. like our own detective stories and best sellers
a parody (paody) a transformation (trasnformation) of actual fact. But in the seats
in the covered part of the house, there were nobles, rulers,
scholars. Their silence (silenc) is harder to explain. For they were
readers (redares); they had the Latins and the Greeks at the back
of their minds. How could it have been that the trained
taste of such spectators (speactoars) received the extraordinary
illumination of these English plays with no more comment

p.sup:
said nothing
about the
[revelation?],
was not
outraged, by
an excited
- as seems to be the common reader to a [illeg.]

div.p:
How can it have been that they made no critical comment
upon this extraordinary xmxmxmxmxmxmmxx revelation of this new
art?

Perhaps in his essays supplies a reason.
"These things be but toyes" he wrote in the essay called
To the aristocratic scholar (sch lar)
the players were still only mountebanks (mo ntebanks) bear leaders and
acrobats. They spoke in the vulgar tongue. Off the stage
they lived in the heart of darkness. lying on the
bed in Deptford reached out and stabbed in the head
whoever in the back. Mr Ingram gave Marlowe a mortal wound then drove his dagger through
Marlowe's (Marloews) eye (eeeye) over his right eye. S through the
body with a sword that cost three and sixpence. So complete
was bacons contempt for this underworld that he could be
tolerant. The stage is more beholding to Love than the
Life of Man..... great spirits and great businesses do keep
out of [this? their?] (thid) weak passion." The proper place for the wak
weak passion was the stage, for love leads to speaking in
perpetual hyperbole.

The proper topic (tipic) of discussion in the upper (upp r) world
was the life of man. The titles (tiles)of the Essays enumerate (enurmate)
enumerate (enurmarte) those topics. "Of Truth. Of Death. Of Unity in
Religion. Of Revenge. Of Simulation and Dissimulation.
Those were the subjects (subjactes) that the rulers discussed at
their high tables. The sediment of that conversation is in
the rich deposits of the essays. He is concerned with the
great world of action; with government; with the tortuous

nature of Princes; with the arts by which rulers can sway,
can coax, and can supress. He lives entirely (netirely) in the
world of great spirits and great business. The common people
is contemptible. "The master of superstition is the People (Peopoe).
Praise "if it be from the common people, it is commonly (commnoly)
false and naught. The lowest virtues draw praise (priase) from them;
the middle virtues work in them Astonishment (Astonihsment); and admiration;
but of the highest vertues they have no sense or perceiving (perceibging)
at all..."

The soul that walked between delicate groves keeps to a
narrow path between hedges. While ranged the world.
mixing (micing) garrulously with everyone, and speculating freely,
kept to the narrow path. Yet even in the shade
his thought is embodied. His deep meditations are given visible (visibe)
xxxxx concrete form. "Nay retire (bretire) men cannot when they would:
neither will they when it were reason; but (bu) are impatient (impateint)
of privateness even in age and sickness which require the
Shadow; Like old Townsmen that will still be sitting at their (ther)
street door, though thereby they offer Age to scorn."
Even in the delicate grove thought is coloured.

p.sup:
The colours that show shew best by candlelight, are:
white, carnation, & a kinde of sea-water green

div.p:
His contempt was for (fr) hyperbole; not for the art of speech.
He was teaching the ranting players to speak slowly, closely
subtly. He was proving that there is another kind of poetry,
the poetry (thepoetry) of prose. He was doing his part to bring the critical (critic) share in bringing the shade
faculty into being. prose of the mind He was making an end of anonymity. There by [making?]

xxx
29

Anonymity was a great possession. It gave the early
writing a general nature. It gave us the ballads (ballds); it
gave us the songs. It allowed us to know nothing of the
mans name. had great privileges. He is not
resopnsible. He is not self conscious. He can borrow.
He can repeat. He can say what every (very) one feels.
No one asks that he shall stamp his own name on his work.
He keeps at a distance from the present moment.
Anon the lyric poet repeats over and over again
that flowers fade; that death is the end (ned). He is never
tired of celebrating red roses and white breasts.
The anonymous playwright has like the singer this nameless
vitality, something (somwthing) drawn from the crowd in the penny
seats and not yet (yey) dead in ourselves. For we too become
anonymous and (nand) forget something that we have learnt
in reading the plays (p;ays) that no one has troubled (troub led) to set a
name to.

But at some point there comes a break when anonymity
withdraws. It comes presumably when the playwright (playwrgight) has
absorbed (abosrbed) the contribution (contrbution) of the audience; and returns it
to them in a single figure which is individual. There is a
moment in play after (aft) play when the audience is no longer
master of the playwright; yet is not separate from him.
A common life still unites them, but the playwright becomes
increasingly diminant. This separation comes fitfully.
Now we say He is speaking our woxmxmxx thoughts.
O (NoO) God, O God that it were possible
To undo things (thin s) done; to call back yesterday.

"But we neednt have been to all that trouble," she
continued "making the Barn ready, for it didnt rain this
year"

"This year, last year, next year, never..." muttered
old . "Tinker, tailor, soldier, sailor..." He was
talking in his sleep.

Lucy slipped her letter into its envelope. It was time
to read her book---the . She had lost her
place. She looked at the pictures; mammoths and mastodons,
and prehistoric birds. Then she found the page where she
had stopped.

The darkness had increased (incrased), and it was cold. With a little
shiver, Mrs Swithin drew her sequin shawl (shalw) about hew shoulders
She was too deep in the story to ask for the window to be
shut. "London" said the author " was (a s) then a swamp...
Thick groves of trees covered the land, and on the top
oftheir matted branches, birds sang..."

The great square of the window showed only sky now.
It was a losing its light; it was svere severe and stone xxxxx
blue. The shadow crept over Bartholomews face. He looked
leafless, spectral. As a dog shudders its skin, his skin
shuddered. He rose, shook himself, glared at nothing,
and stalked from the room. They hard the paws padding
on the carpet behind him.

Lucy turned the page quickly, guiltily,
like a child who will be told to go to bed before it reaches (raches)
the end of the chapter. Pre-historic man, she read, half
human, half monster, rose from his semi-crouching position

Now we note the beauty of the words.
But often it is a suspended, derelict beauty. Chaos intervenes (inter)
intervenes (venes). The relation (rl ation) of part to part is outraged.
The balance is imperfect. Here is profusion; there bareness.
The anonymous (anony ous) playwright is irresponsible. He cares nothing
has no conscieince about truth; he cares only for the plot.
We are left in the end without an end. The emotion is e
wasted.

But gradually (graudally) the mist withdraws. So many playwrights (playwrgihts)
are exploring (explroing) So many private people are pressing up
their weight of unexpressed (unepxpressed) emotion upon the writers
consciousness (conscious ess). Country squires are finding themselves (themsleves) able
to say what they think without quoting .
The curtain (curatin) rises incessantly (incesaantly) upon play after play.
Every Each time, with [illeg.] it rises upon a more complex, highly matured drama.
After it has risen again and again it rises finally upon
upon the completely embodied; and upon the completely
controlled. It rises upon and and
and . Finally it rises upon . But the play
has outgrown the uncovered theatre where the sun beats and
the rain pours. The theatre must be replaced
by the theatre of the brain. is replaced by the man
who writes a book. The audience is replaced by the the
reader. Anon, when is dead.
